thread.title: High-school football | Gamble pays off for Hilliard Davidson against Upper Arlington
thread.title_full: High-school football | Gamble pays off for Hilliard Davidson against Upper Arlington

title: High-school football | Gamble pays off for Hilliard Davidson against Upper Arlington
text:
OHSAA decision hurts central Ohio golf squads By Steve Blackledge The Columbus Dispatch • Saturday October 10, 2015 6:29 AM 
It shouldn’t have surprised anyone when Hilliard Davidson coach Brian White opted to go for it on fourth-and-1 at his 29-yard-line early in the second quarter against Upper Arlington on Friday. 
Throughout his 17 years at Davidson, White has shown a penchant for gambling — and succeeding — in similar situations. 
“To the people in the stands, I’m a genius if we make it and (an idiot) if we don’t,” White said. “All I know is I’ve got a hot running back who I trust with my life, and I like my odds of him picking up the first down.” 
>> High-school football results, box scores from Week 7 
Ryan Royer did that and a lot more, breaking a 71-yard touchdown run that turned the tide for host Davidson in a 16-7 victory in Ohio Capital Conference Central Division play. 
To that point, Upper Arlington led 7-3 and had picked up eight first downs to one for Davidson. 
“The fact that I went through a stacked line to the goal line basically untouched is a testament to my line and the kick-out blocks I got from my backs,” said Royer, who finished with 253 yards and two touchdowns on 31 carries. 
“No doubt, this play came at a really key time for us. It was a huge momentum swing for us. Upper Arlington had just drove the field and scored on us. We needed a lift. The thing is, I had two long TD runs in similar situations against Central Crossing (two weeks ago) when everyone knew what was coming. The line just buckled down and got it done.” 
Upper Arlington had taken the opening kickoff and put together a 14-play, 80-yard drive capped by Danny Logan’s 4-yard touchdown run. He finished with 89 yards. 
Davidson countered with a 48-yard field goal by Robert LeFevre on its next series. 
Upper Arlington continued to control the ball until Royer’s 71-yard TD run gave Davidson a 10-7 lead. 
Later in the half, Upper Arlington quarterback Vince Murdocco mishandled an errant shotgun snap, and Davidson’s Zac Uphouse recovered near midfield. 
Royer capped an 11-play drive with a 1-yard TD run just before halftime that made it 16-7. The extra-point kick was blocked. 
Upper Arlington (5-2, 2-2) had several scoring opportunities in the second half but was stymied by a fumble, a missed field-goal attempt and two fourth-down stops. 
“We had the ability to do some things tonight, but turnovers hurt us, and we just didn’t execute well enough,” UA coach Joel Cutler said. “They outperformed us and outcoached us. Hand it to Royer. He’s a tough kid. That big play really hurt us, but we still had plenty of chances after that and just couldn’t get it done in the red zone.” 
Royer, a junior who played cornerback last season, has come into his own for Davidson (6-1, 4-0). 
“He’s gotten so much better since week one,” White said. “He was a good running back then, but he has turned into a real good one between then and now. His balance and vision really set him apart, and he’s always falling forward for yardage.” 
Davidson has won seven straight in the series for a 15-5 lead. 
sblackledge@dispatch.com
